text: this is thomas fuller reporting from
siem reap cambodia Cambodia's ancient
temples are among the finest
architectural wonders in asia some still
shrouded by jungle but in recent decades
is Civil War rack the country many
temples were difficult to reach or at
worst were totally inaccessible now with
financing from several foreign
governments and the Asian Development
Bank hundreds of miles of roads are
being completed and projects involving
more than a thousand more miles of
pavement are underway workers are
literally digging up Cambodia's violent
past and paving over it here soldiers
search for landmines and ordnance before
construction of the road can begin Road
building is a big deal in Cambodia a
national priority to unify the ones
fractured country in December Prime
Minister Hun Sen came to inaugurate one
of the country's most important roads
that connects Thailand with Cambodia's
capital Phnom Penh
roots number five and six were initially
constructed during French colonial times
but amid the chaos and neglected Civil
War they fell into disrepair and in
recent years were among the worst roads
in Asia it was bumpy really rugged and
in the rainy season he was muddy and
slippery costs a lot of accidents and
your vehicles would get really dirty the
potholes were legendary and the choking
dust was a health hazard
the journey from Bangkok to siem reap
home to the ancient temples at angkor
wat used to take about 10 hours now if
you leave it breakfast you might be able
to make it to Siem Reap in time for
lunch certainly for dinner I don't sell
as much as before because people speak
past here but I'm happier with the new
road because I'm healthier these new
roads are modest start for Cambodia two
lanes that pass beside rice paddies and
through villages and towns the
transition from battlefield two major
tourist destination means that towns
like Siem Reap now resemble a small city
and remote temples such as prayer be
here now beckon
